4.1 Types of Verse and Sound Devices

        Completion requirements
        



If you haven't done so already, download the Study Guide for unit 4, you can open it in Google docs. or any word
    processing application. Use the study guide to make notes; it will help you identify and practice the key concepts in the unit. The study guide is available as a PDF too.


The Patterns of Poetry
Poetry is the oldest and most difficult literary art form to read, write, and understand. Poetry is heavily encoded: it uses much figurative language in very few words. Poetry is also highly rhythmic and lyrical (song-like), using sound to
    achieve a tone to match its message.  
In general, there are two types of verse: fixed and free verse. Fixed verse is poetry that uses a kind of template that limits its line length or sound devices. Examples of fixed verse poetry forms are the haiku, sonnet, or
    limerick. These poems each have a set number of syllables, lines, or rhyming patterns that fit a standardized format. Usually, a fixed verse poem has about the same number of line lengths throughout. Therefore, its overall shape
    is that of a square or rectangle.  
A free verse poem, on the other hand, has no template, no set number of syllables, lines, or rhyme scheme. Free verse lines can be as short as a word and as long as a paragraph. Sometimes, a free verse poem's lines can run
    off the page. Free verse poems can be identified easily by their line length variation.  
When reading a poem, look for repetition or patterns at the beginning and ends of lines. Look for transitions, or voltas (turns), that signal a change in tone. A sonnet, for example, usually has a volta (a
    turn) in line 9 of 14 in order to move from problem to solution or from cause to effect.
